audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker starting off in an excited tone, stating the listener is here for "one reason and one reason only," to understand a visual timer. The speaker transitions into a more instructive tone, saying, "Perfect. I'm going to teach you how to do it," promising to be direct. He instructs the listener, "First things first, you want to go to live split."

The clip begins with a male speaker introducing a link in the description, instructing listeners to click it, visit the page, and download. He then advises creating a new folder on the desktop and dragging the file into it. He describes opening the file and moving its contents to the new folder. Next, he instructs listeners to open LiveSplit by double-clicking an executable file, and explains that the window that appears is their timer. He moves on to opening the "edit splits" feature, introducing the next stage of the process.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker describing steps for a game, specifically mentioning "choose the game" and typing in "Minecraft." He then mentions the "run category" as a subheading. Continuing, he explains adding the game name and category before putting in splits. Throughout this section, his tone is instructional.

The clip begins with a male speaker explaining the concept of breaking down a game into smaller segments to track progress. He uses a Minecraft speedrun as an example, stating they will have "four splits." He proceeds to describe the process of adding four segments and titles them "Overworld," "Nether," "End Portal Search," and "Ender Dragon," ending the segment on a neutral tone.

A male speaker begins in a conversational tone, giving instructions on how to add icons to splits, stating to "double-click on this icon" and choose the file. He mentions icons he has chosen and offers them to viewers. He then discusses how to edit the layout by right-clicking and adjusting the total number of splits in the settings. Moving on, he suggests using a horizontal line instead of a small box and touches on self-explanatory settings. The speaker proposes adding 'spicy things' such as a more detailed timer, suggesting to go to the timer menu and click detailed timer and add or remove as desired. Further options for customization include adding sound effects from media, MP3 files.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker explaining how to add hotkeys, suggesting to right-click the window and click settings, which opens a hotkeys window. He notes the first five settings are the most commonly used, but explains he will focus on the first three for the tutorial. He tells the listener how to change the hotkey, provides the example of insert, and explains how to reset and undo split. He advises selecting uncommon keys, then recommends turning on global keys to allow the same hotkeys to affect the timer, regardless of which window is in focus. The speaker encourages resizing the window and then begins to explain the different colors of the split, such as blue for finishing a speedrun, as well as positive red, minus gold, and minus green indicators, describing their meaning. He apologizes for a "stream inception" before explaining they're going to import the LiveSplit window onto their OBS scene.

The clip begins with one male speaker starting instructions by stating that they will be clicking the plus icon. He describes the window capture feature, asking listeners to create a new window and label it "Live Split". He explains how to choose a window and make sure it has "Live Split" selected. The man states that this will allow the audience to see the "Live Split" window on their stream, explaining the distinction between what is visible on OBS versus the desktop.

The audio clip begins with one male speaker describing how changing the window size of LightSplit on his desktop changes the window itself in OBS, implying a convenient way to change dimensions for OBS. He speaks in an informative, slightly technical tone.

The clip starts with a single male speaker explaining a workaround in LiveSplit for a transparent look. He sounds informative and instructional. The speaker mentions "edit layout," "layout settings," and changing background color, giving specific recommendations for colors to use. Then he goes on to "previous segment" and "vertical" as well as "opacity." This is followed by music of an electronic style, presumably from a streamer setup, playing in the background, mixed with speech in the foreground. The speaker shifts from discussing LiveSplit to explaining filters and chroma key, noting the automatic default of green but again suggesting custom color options. He notes that "green was too similar" to "icons that we already have" and mentions icons are "green screened."

A single male speaker gives instructions, advising the listener to right-click, click "save splits," and then "save layout." He emphasizes that doing so will prevent resets in LiveSplit, maintaining progress. The speaker sounds instructional and reassuring.

The audio clip starts with an upbeat, electronic music piece, creating an energetic mood with synthesizers and a driving rhythm. This transitions into a male speaker who begins by encouraging viewers to like, comment, and learn more. He expresses gratitude and directs listeners to his Twitch and YouTube channels for more content before thanking them again and announcing the end of the video. The clip concludes by returning to the upbeat electronic music, sustaining the initial energetic mood.
